#Text=4. OLSR Protocol
#Text=The optimized link state routing protocol is one of the most used protocols in MANETs .
#Text=It is part of the table-driven ( proactive ) routing protocols that build the routing tables by periodically exchanging topology control messages .
#Text=The OLSR has adopted the MPR concept to achieve good dissemination of TC messages .
#Text=The MPR concept optimizes the overhead , firstly , by selecting the minimum number of nodes to act as forwarders of TC messages .
#Text=Secondly , only links between MPRs and their selectors are shared to reduce the size of TC messages .
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=shows the principle of the MPR concept .
#Text=We model the OLSR network as a unit disk graph , where V represents the set of nodes and E the set of symmetric edges .
#Text=is the signal length of the node u .
#Text=For simplicity , we consider that signal range R is uniform for all nodes .
#Text=Two nodes u and v form a symmetric link if and only if they are at distance .
#Text=The OLSR protocol maintains regularly local information and global information in each node .
#Text=Neighborhood information is broadcasted via HELLO messages by each node u in the network .
#Text=The HELLO messages are never forwarded and they serve to discover one-hop and two-hop neighbor sets denoted and , respectively .
#Text=Every node elects from its neighbors a set of nodes to act as MPRs to forward TC messages .
#Text=We denote the set of MPRs of a node u as and the set of MPR selectors as .
#Text=A node u updates its topology information information each time a HELLO or a TC message is received .
#Text=The topology information on a node u is a directed subgraph of the graph G denoted .
#Text=In this section , we describe the MPR concept of OLSR , especially the MPR selection and the default forwarding rules ( DFR ) of TC messages .
#Text=4.1.
#Text=The MPR Computation of OLSR
#Text=The OLSR exchanges HELLO messages on a regular interval to sense links between nodes , to discover one-hop and two-hop neighbors and to build a local topology .
#Text=HELLO messages are exchanged in broadcast manner and they are never forwarded to other nodes .
#Text=A device informs , within the HELLO messages , its adjacent nodes about its links with other nodes .
#Text=The MPR set is computed every time a HELLO message is received .
#Text=A node selects among its one-hop neighbors the minimum number of MPRs to cover its two-hop neighbors .
#Text=After the MPR computation is completed , all the two-hop neighbors are covered .
#Text=The MPR collection should be as small as possible .
#Text=The smaller the MPR collection is , the lower the overhead would be .
#Text=Let us consider the OLSR network presented in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=, and .
